segments.text: So we're now looking into salinity power, a thing that's very little recognized.
For instance, when that brine flows into the Colorado River and it's diluted, the free energy is as though that brine has fallen down a 7,000-foot dam.
7,000-foot dam.
That's high energy density.
If you're going to let it get in the Colorado anyway, why, you might as well get the power out of it.
Now, that's kind of a foolish thing, because if you're going to dam it up, why, you might as well shoot it in the Gulf and get the power out of it.
But this is something we're now working on, which is salinity power.
It's a totally invisible sort of power.
But every little agricultural drainage ditch that's going into the Great Salt Lake, for instance, has a megawatt per cubic foot per second.
is the free energy of that going into the Great Salt Lake.
It's the highest of all the natural forms of energy.
It's certainly the most concentrated, the natural forms of energy of that certain level, not coal or oil or lightning, of course.
So we're not going to overlook it, and we're trying to see.
It's a strange sort of energy because of the curiosities of saltwater.
But that's a whole other subject.
I don't know whether you want to go into it or not.
No, I want to know one thing now.
Why is saltwater energy?
Only one thing?
Well, I want to know a lot, but I want to know one thing immediately.
Why is saltwater energy differently construed than freshwater energy?
Oh, well, no.
You've got me wrong.
OK.
If you take, say, brine and mix it with fresh water, but you could mix it with seawater because it's so much more concentrated.
If you separate them by a semipermeable membrane, osmotic membrane, and allow this to go to equilibrium, the fresh water would go into this brine.
And if you allow this to take place without much dilution,
It would raise the brine 7,000 feet.
You could now pour it off up there and run a Pelton well with it or something and generate energy.
Well, this is a real expression of the free energy.
The peculiarity about the thing is that if you release that much energy in a reaction like putting brine with fresh water together, you would expect it to heat up.
If you release that much energy, the energy's got to go somewhere.
You'd expect it to heat up, but it doesn't.
The temperature changes automatically.
essentially nothing.
And that's because of the peculiarities of the substance sodium chloride.
Sodium chloride has a strange property.
Almost nothing else has it.
And that is that it produces disorder in the water at just about the rate it releases energy.
So it all goes into what's called entropy.

Now, if the Great Salt Lake had been anything other than sodium chloride, let's say it had been magnesium sulfate, people on their inner tubes floating down the little streams in the Great Salt Lake would have burned their ears off.
Or if it had been something else, ammonium nitrate, God forbid, or ammonium sulfate.
Yeah, ammonium sulfate.
There are frozen errors.
There have been big temperature changes when that fresh water flowed in.
Nobody would ever doubt that there was plenty of energy.

But because sodium chloride is the dominant ion, there's a dominant molecule in there, electrolyte in there, what happens is that the energy is soaked up into increasing heat capacity at just the rate it's made.
And so it doesn't appear as temperature.
It's there perfectly well in a different form.
All we have to do is learn how to utilize it.
It's a tremendous lot.
You see, all of the Midwest is underlain by brines, as you may know.
And there's also Texas, as God knows, your oil wells.
When do they quit drilling?
When they hit brine.
And that all is a power source, every bit of it, and by no means an inconsiderable one.
Did you first become interested in the issue of food and food expansion through the ocean when you were in Pakistan?
No, I've always been more or less interested in it.
For a long time, yeah.
I was 62, I think.
When did you interview Ravel?
Oh, over the July the 4th weekend.
You did, huh?
Yeah.
He's an interesting guy, a great guy.
At his home?
Yeah.
Yeah.
No, I was...

What I want to know is what, as a man involved in oceans, looking and has been looking a long time at things like food production, mariculture, what was the impact on you psychologically in an underdeveloped country for the first time like Pakistan?
Well, that wasn't exactly the first time I'd been in that country.
Your reaction to a country like that, of course, is very complicated.
And one can spend hours talking about that one subject.
A little peculiar, isn't it?
There is so much misery.
There's so much poverty.
And people accept it so well.
The most frightening thing, probably, about India and Pakistan is how fast you can get used to it.
I mean, you shouldn't be able to get used to it.
You should not be able to get used to it.
Yet, you know, these people are not without their total disadvantages.
I mean, without all the advantages in some way.
You look at all the crippled people in that country and the defective people.
You see them on the streets, and you're horrified by it.
What do we do with our defective people in the United States?
We hide them.
They have a hell of a poor time, don't they?
They're old people, the old crippled people, the insane people.
They're all hidden somewhere.
I mean, even people just with bad facial scars.
They're hidden.
That country, those people, at any rate, have a better time, don't they?
They're with society.
And those are kind of interesting points, it seems to me.
The United States has such a culture of perfection, you see.
You really can't even be bald, much less have your nose missing.
or a disfiguration, crippled iron or something.
That country, those people live much freer lives.
So as I say, what would our society look like if we really left all of our people on the streets and accepted them?
Quite different.
And the old people, the old crippled people,
that would be on the streets in India and Pakistan are hidden away in our country and living miserable lives.
OK. As a matter of fact, I was talking to a Texan on the airplane just about that the other day.
I said, well, you sure got a point there.
He said, never thought I would.
Yeah.
Remind me, does this turn your work into a
I've been to India quite a bit because my sister lived there for 20 years or 18 years, yeah.
And?
In India.
In what capacity?
Well, her husband was an architect, and she's an artist, and they built buildings and designed buildings and built schools.
They built the University of Karachi and the Institute of Buddhist Studies at...
at the heavens in Burma.
And quite a number of structures throughout India.
And I used to visit there occasionally, or visit them.
So I was not totally unacquainted with that area.
OK. Now, in 1968, I had bootstrap course.
Oh, yeah.
That was kind of fun.
And a statement of fact, are you asking me?
Well, I'm asking you how it came about.
Well, that was an idea.
And I'm not so sure how well it's ever going to be utilized.
But it was an idea of a car that pulled itself down without these tremendous weights that you use for car barrels.
and took a long core with a very light core.
I think it's the only core that ever took a core that weighed much more than the device itself.

And it's just an interesting configuration of a core, it seems to me, that is not without merit for taking very long cores to the ocean bottom with simple equipment so that you don't have to have these immense winches, very large cores.
Now, it seems to me that in more recent years...
I'd like your wife's opinion on that.
I'll write you and tell you as a matter of fact.
It appears that in recent years you've published more on marine biology problems, such as fisheries and productivity.
That was the reason for my question about Pakistan.
Why a turn in this direction?
Well, I don't think it's a turn, exactly.
It's a culmination of some ideas that I've been working on for quite a few years.
Different theories, alternate theories of food webs, how they're put together.
The marine biologist, are you on?
Yes.
The marine biologist suffers from, I think, the delusion that he can see everything that goes forth, that goes on in the ocean.
Given enough...
plankton nets, enough ships, enough graduate students, and one thing or another, you can trace what happens to the food material in the ocean.
I think that's totally a delusion.
You can't do it.
The food web is far too complicated.
Just take the curious case of reproductive products.
Every adult creature in the ocean is throwing out eggs and sperm, which account for maybe
50% of the potential growth of that population.
And it's all invisibly flowing down into the food web.
You see, we're so misled by our terrestrial experience.
We think that the immediate effect of reproduction is to add to the adult stocks by direct transfer of biomass.
That is, a cow has a calf.
The calf is a large proportion of an adult.
It feeds on paternal sources.
It immediately then, after it has weaned,
feeds on the same source that the adults feed on, and adds to the adult biomass.
The ocean is a totally different situation, except for the marine mammals and some sharks.
This isn't the way it is at all.
The reproductive products are subtracted from the adult biomass.
The eggs are pulled out of the adult biomass.
The amount of survival of that material that comes back to the adult is absolutely zero.
The egg that survives down here goes through the larval form, juvenile form, and finally becomes an adult.
The survival of that egg is zero in that.
So we forget that the ocean is in many respects opposed, opposite, than the land.
Reproductive products, which are a major tax on all creatures, is not added to the adult biomass in the ocean, but subtracted from it.
And I think we need these kinds of totally different viewpoints.
And we need to formalize them in some way.
And that's what I've been doing the last few years.
You see, we're much misled by the fact that we're terrestrial creatures.
The ocean is, to a great extent, a foreign and dimly understood
system and the life in it is differently adapted.
We forget those differences.
We tend to treat it like if we were, like if we were land ecology.
Is it fair to say that you're more optimistic about food production from the oceans than your colleagues?
I don't, I wouldn't speak for my colleagues, but I'm quite optimistic about food production in the ocean, yes.
I think we've got to understand that we have to act rationally.
I don't think we can act as sort of a way of, for instance, passing a law that we must protect the porpoises.
We have to first understand what's the relationship between porpoises and tuna.
It may be in the 30 or 40 years of intensive tuna fishery that we've greatly stimulated the porpoise.
It may be they're in all out of proportion.
It's a marvelous to me that tuna can survive in competition of the porpoise.
profligate, warm-blooded animal inhabiting the ocean.
If you've ever seen a school of purpose to sweep through a gulf, it's incredible.
Frothing water where they clean everything out as they go.

Now, isn't it funny that we should, because of soft hearts or something, should now have passed a law that says, ah, we must do this thing, which may be the worst possible tactic, is to pull the tuna out without hurting the purpose, which are in direct competition with one another.
Or do we know whether they're in direct competition?
Do we know that 40 years of tuna fishery has stimulated the porpoise or not?
Do we know that they're in abnormal abundance or normal abundance?
We don't know.
We just passed a law that says you've got to protect the porpoise.
That may really extinguish the tuna fishery.
You see, all our marine fisheries are conducted in this way that stimulate the unwanted species.
We have no use for the porpoise.
Even the Japanese can hardly use it.
And by law now, we make a technique that reduces the wanted species and increases the unwanted species.
I went up to British Columbia not long ago, and here they have radio advisories to the salmon fishery about where you can fish without getting your net full of dogfish.
Now, this is the same technique as the boy that learns how to catch the trout out of the pond without catching a sucker, isn't he?
He increases the suckers and decreases the trout.
Now, here's a whole organization to decrease the salmon and increase the dogfish.
You see, you've got to take the weeds.
The fisheries in the world are conducted like a blind man who can't see the weeds in his garden.
is always pulling up the corn instead of the weeds, and then wondering why he's got less and less corn each year.
So are you suggesting, then, that more study ought to be done?
Well, I'm just trying to point out these viewpoints, which are different than the conventional, the traditional way in which people have gone to look at these things.
Many people say that fishing is already an optimal.
that the ocean cannot produce many more fisheries, that fisheries are very inefficient.
It depends on what level you do this, of course, doesn't it?
And what level you conduct your fisheries.
We're conducting, if you were to look at it in terrestrial terms, we're conducting our fisheries now as though we were trying to feed the human race on tigers.
It just takes too god-amany cows to feed the tigers, doesn't it?
Actually, we're probably even higher than that.
Whatever eats tigers, I've forgotten.
Is there anything?
We're conducting our fisheries at that level.
No tribe in this right mind ever tried to feed itself on tigers.
Took too many deer or buffalo or whatever it was.
So the closer we get down to things like the Anchiveta fishery and Drew and so forth, the larger and larger, and the more we go towards the juveniles.
The mortality of these things in the ocean is so great that
probably we are justified in taking juvenile.
But the thing we do have to do is see what the effects of our fishery are on the competitors.
We're always stimulating the competitors of what we want to catch.
Those kind of things have to be pointed out.
Yet the law is so indirect that there's really no way to have any flexibility, you see.
There is no way to set up a commercial fishery that really trims and controls a fishery in multi-species modes that it should.
There's no theory to handle it.
I tried to develop a theory, and it looks like it might make some sense.
What was joint task force number one?
to whom you submitted numerous secret reports.
That was the Joint Task Force bikini hunt.
First test.
Abel and Baker test.
Now much of the material you published from 45 to 47 from Berkeley was related to the physical surveillances of beaches along the Pacific.
Was this defense information for amphibious landings primarily?
Well, it was more general than that.

It was trying to understand the nature of beaches and amphibious landings wherever it was, not defending the Pacific coast against amphibious landings, no, but rather guarding our own amphibious landing.
Could you describe any work that you did on sea mines that's no longer classified?
What were you?
Oh, boy.
Let's see.
Can I come up with that?
Well, as I said very early, there's quite a bit I can't certainly still classify.
Quite different ideas about sea mines.
One thing I can say is I took almost a year off back in 1952 or so, 53 maybe, to study land mines.
under the theory that landmine is essentially the same kind of a weapon as a sea mine, except it has the ability to evolve much more rapidly.

Every Texas farmer that gets into the army thinks he can go out and play around with some primacord and explosives and develop a new landmine, and nobody in their right mind fiddles around with a sea mine.
There you're talking about you're on a ship.
You can't possibly screw around being innovative.
with 300 pounds of TNT.
But everybody feels they know something about landmines and they can make innovation.
And there are some tremendous innovations in landmines.
In fact, they'd have near beat us in Korea and in Vietnam also.
The innovations were tremendous.
What I was trying to see was
Does this evolution of landmines have a forecasting ability on the evolution of sea mines?
Are some of these technologies that were developed and which were so extremely difficult to combat that were developed with landmines by small-scale innovation transferable to sea mines?
I thought that was a reasonably good contribution I made on that subject.
And here you have an evolutionary sequence that you can begin to understand and what the steps have been between measures and countermeasures and counter-countermeasures and so forth.
See if those were transferable into the ocean, and indeed they are.
Is nuclear blasting to form harbors and channels still a feasible idea?
Oh, sure.
The Russians have been doing it, of course.
It's not a feasible idea for the United States to do.
I think the French might do it to make harbors.
Those great harbors of Bikini, I rode around in one of them two weeks after the blast.
Beautiful, vast, blue harbors that make supertankers...
A reality.
Bring in a 200-foot draft ship and it can be made like that.
But the whole plowshare program was conducted with such insensitivity, I think, that it does not become a possibility for the United States to proceed in any way.
You know, they were going to blast a channel through the Sierra Nevadas to let the smog out of Los Angeles or
Start out with blasting a new sea level canal through Panama.
Things that scared people to death.
Were you involved, by the way, with that plan to open up a new Panama Canal?
To some extent, yeah.
Did you think it were a feasible idea?
From an engineering standpoint?
Yeah, from an engineering standpoint.
Of course.
From an engineering standpoint, from a social standpoint.
From a social engineering standpoint, it was idiocy.
You've got to start out small on something like that.
You know what I want to do?
I want to take my family and go out to Bikini and live around the edges of the crater out there and take some National Geographic-type articles and live on the lip of a nuclear crater.
This great mile and a half
It was 300 feet deep.
There was new fish coming in, new corals, new development in one thing or another.
That was kind of the way that one wanted to feed this into the social system.
A National Geographic harbor of a family of scientists went out and lived on the lips of a bikini crater.
That would have made sense to me.
To me, too.
What happened to that idea?
I didn't get anywhere with it.
In fact, some of my best writing is undoubtedly in proposals that never got funded.
My most persuasive, my most thoughtful, my most penetrating writing is lost in proposals.
There.
OK. What is the future of deep sea ports?
Open sea ports?
Open sea ports.
Oh, well, of course.
As far as petroleum and liquid fuels and things like that, it's gigantic.
That's where it's all going to be conducted.
Ships are going to be built at sea, are being built at sea, assembled at sea at any rate, and they're never going to touch shore.
You consider this inevitable?
It's not only inevitable, it's here.
What about the idea of the proposed sea dock in the Gulf?
I don't know.
Anything about the sea dock in the Gulf?
Well, the concept of- Is that a physician?
A hospital?
Hospital.
So in other words, is it fair to say that you see these docks being built for the transport of oil in places like the Gulf here and the Gulf of California?
I don't know if they're going to be docks.
They're going to be monobuies of some sort, I think.
Why should they be docks?
But I see no reason.
Well, one thing I really don't understand.
You can perhaps elucidate me.
Huh?
What is the tremendous virtue of a free port?
I mean, look at Hong Kong.
Well, of course, now it's a special case because it's an outlet of goods from mainland China.
But free ports around the world prosper tremendously.
What happens if you have a free port right in the middle of the ocean somewhere?
All the ships have to come in and trade goods.
You can have a nuclear power plant there to run it.
It's a big enclosed thing.
You can do some
have some fisheries, all kinds of things you can do that would not be accepted in coastal waters, like the release of fisheries waste and so on, nuisance level of nuclear waste.
And you can have a free port.
Is there virtue in having just a free port out in the middle of the ocean somewhere where people can trade without tax?
What is it?
I'm not sure countries can move any longer to free trade.
I'm not sure countries can move any longer to free trade.
They can.
I'm not sure that's economically feasible for countries.
Well, very few of them have... Well, export limits are much fewer than import limits.
So, in principle, you can have some sort of free trade in the middle of the sea.
Is this an idiotic idea?
No.
You don't think so?
No.
What about spillhouses, cities on the sea?
I think that's all fun.
And John Craven, too, of course, is working on this.
That's all great fun.
I don't know why people want to live there.
I can count a billion places where you could sit down in Los Angeles and never find it again, but most of the world is uninhabited, as you well know.
It's only these coastal strips that is covered over by this incrustation of human beings.
